titleStmt.title: The neuroeconomics of social influence and contagion

affiliation.orgName: Centre for Human Brain Health School of Psychology University of Birmingham Birmingham

analytic.title: The neuroeconomics of social influence and contagion

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: People often adjust their behaviours and preferences to align with others, a phenomenon termed social influence or social contagion. Social influence can have a profound effect on our economic preferences, with important implications for financial decision-making and making rational choices. Here we review recent findings in neuroeconomics, elucidating the psychological, computational, and neural mechanisms that underpin social influence during value-based decision-making. We examine how others' decisions can shift our own economic preferences, regarding risk-taking, temporal discounting, effort discounting, and moral preferences. Additionally, we discuss the lifespan similarities and differences in susceptibility to social influence. Finally, we cover studies revealing the neural basis of susceptibility to social influence and highlight key common brain areas across studies that could underpin these effects. We end by considering the implications of strong evidence of susceptibility to social influence on economic preferences, the challenges and opportunities of this influence and how future studies could harness it to create positive changes across the lifespan.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Humans are ultra-social animals. They are deeply interdependent on one another and use social information to shape behaviour and cognition (Dunbar & Shultz, 2007;Tomasello, 2014).

This interdependence often leads people to change their behaviour and preferences to align with others, a phenomenon known as social influence (Cialdini & Goldstein, 2004) or social contagion (Wheeler, 1966). Understanding how and why people are susceptible to social influence is of paramount importance at the individual and societal level. For example, in the context of political decision-making and social cohesion (Andrews et al., 2020;Bavel et al., 2020;Miller & Prentice, 2016) where misinformation contributes to negative outcomes. In the context of economic decision-making, knowing how others influence our own financial decisions is crucial for avoiding financial exploitation and making rational economic choices.

In this chapter, we outline the latest research on the psychological, computational and neural mechanisms underlying social influence within the framework of neuroeconomics. We describe how social influence drives shifts in preferences during value-based decision-making, a process that entails weighing rewards -such as monetary gains -against costs, including how long we need to wait, how uncertain an outcome is, and how much effort is involved. We will also consider how these processes develop and differ across the lifespan and in health and disease.

div.head: Social influence
div.p: Early work on social influence showed just how powerful other people's preferences can be on our own. In the pioneering studies of Sherif (1935) and Asch (1956), they demonstrated that knowing the preferences of a group can change our own perception. Two lines were shown to a group of people. One line was clearly bigger than the other. If the majority of members of the group intentionally misreported that the smallest line was the biggest, this was enough to change the report of an independent individual who was not a confederate of the experimenter.

Researchers propose that two distinct yet interconnected motivations underlie this form of social influence (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955;Toelch & Dolan, 2015). Firstly, people are motivated to align with others when conformity is itself rewarded -a process known as 'normative influence'. This influence helps people adapt to their social environment or fit within a social group, allowing them to demonstrate belonging and signal membership by following established group norms. In such cases, conformity is often rewarded with social approval, which strengthens or maintains social relationships, and helps people avoid social punishment such as ostracism. Secondly, conformity may not always be directly rewarded, but its outcomes can be beneficial or advantageous, a process known as 'informational influence'. This type of influence helps people adopt the most appropriate behaviour in uncertain situations, especially when they believe others have better information or knowledge.
In such cases, people view others as a valuable source of information, aiding them in making more accurate decisions.

A simple example makes this distinction clearer. Imagine you have just moved to a foreign country and are unfamiliar with the local customs. You go to a restaurant with your new local friends and notice several cups of water on the table. Instead of drinking the water, you observe everyone else using it to clean their cutlery. Although surprised by this behaviour, you are guided by informational influence and follow suit, assuming it is the appropriate thing to do in this context. Later, during the dinner, everyone orders a local dish that you are not keen on trying. To avoid standing out and to fit in with the group, normative influence prompts you to order the same dish.

In addition to these common mechanisms driving social influence, people sometimes change their behaviour or preferences after simply learning what others value (Garvert et al., 2015;Moutoussis et al., 2016), even without experiencing group pressure (absent normative influence) or when there is no obvious benefit (absent informational influence). This type of non-rewarded social conformity is a compelling form of social influence and has been studied in terms of how it can change our economic preferences.

div.head: Social influence on economic preferences
div.p: One way to test social influence within the field of neuroeconomics is to examine whether people's economic preferences can be shifted to be more aligned with one another. In the following sections, we will review the effect of social influence on different types of economic preferences: risk-taking attitude, temporal discounting, effort discounting, and moral preference. Example of a monetary lottery task with a choice between two options with explicitly stated probabilities and rewards: a secure option providing a certain smaller reward and a risky alternative providing a potentially larger reward under uncertainty. Green full circles represent a guaranteed smaller reward, while the red and green 'spinner' represents a probabilistic outcome, offering either no reward or a larger reward (e.g., Devaine & Daunizeau, 2017)

div.head: . (B)
div.p: Example of a temporal discounting task with a choice between an immediate smaller reward and a delayed larger reward (e.g., Garvert et al., 2015). (C) Example of a physical effort discounting task with a choice between a more effortful option with a higher reward and a less effortful option with a lower reward (e.g., Chong et al., 2017). (D) Example of a moral decisionmaking task involving a trade-off between self-interest and the welfare of others (e.g., Crockett et al., 2014). In this task, participants choose between a harmful option (high reward for themselves and high cost for others) and a helpful option (low reward for self and low cost for others). The lightning bolt signifies the number of painful electric shocks delivered to another person. 6

div.head: Risk-taking attitude
div.p: Economic risk can be defined as the variance of potential monetary outcomes, assuming the decision maker is aware of the objective probability distribution of these outcomes (Schonberg et al., 2011). Risk-taking attitudes reflect the level of risk people are willing to accept in exchange for a specific reward (Figner & Weber, 2011). People's risk-taking attitudes have substantial implications across various contexts, from substance abuse to high-risk stock investments (Dohmen et al., 2011;Platt & Huettel, 2008). Risk-taking attitudes are often assessed through monetary lottery tasks, which examine how people make decisions under risk (Rigoli et al., 2016;Sokol-Hessner et al., 2009;Tom et al., 2007). In such tasks, participants are asked to choose between two options with clearly stated probabilities and rewards: a secure option offering a guaranteed reward, and a risky option offering a potentially larger reward under uncertainty ( Figure 1A). For instance, would you prefer £40 for sure or £100 with a probability of 50%? A risk-neutral person would base their choice on the objectively calculated expected value of each option, leading them to select the latter. In contrast, a riskaverse person might prioritise the value of the secure option over the risky one, making them more likely to choose the guaranteed outcome. Conversely, a risk-seeking person might favour the option with a potentially higher reward, even if it also entails a greater potential loss.

Intriguingly, studies have demonstrated that our own attitudes toward risk can be modulated by observing other's risky behaviour. In one study, the authors used a social contagion-based risky gambling task to examine how risk-taking attitudes were influenced by others (Suzuki et al., 2016). The task included three types of trials: participants made their own choices between a risky gamble and a guaranteed $10 (Self trials), observed the choices of two other people (one who was more risk-averse and the other who was more risk-seeking; Observe trials), and predicted the decisions that these people would make (Predict trials). Some experimental blocks included only Self trials, while others required participants to alternate among all three trial types. They found that participants' behaviour showed a contagion effect, their risk-taking preferences shifted toward those of the people they observed and predicted (Figure 2), regardless of whether others were more risk-averse or more risk-seeking. This finding replicated in an independent behavioural experiment. In another study with a similar design, participants were asked to choose between a secure lottery (90% winning a smaller reward) and a risky lottery (lower probability of getting a larger reward) before and after predicting other's choices (Devaine & Daunizeau, 2017). They again found a social contagion effect and that the extent of contagion was linked to the estimated differences between participants' own risk-taking preferences and those of others. Another study about social influence on gambling, conducted within the context of a group of three, also found participants' risk-taking 7 preferences shifted to align with those of the majority in the group (Chung et al., 2015).

Importantly, they also revealed that the extent of social influence was modulated by the similarity between participants and people in the group; that is, people were more influenced by a majority whose risk-taking attitudes were consistent with their own.

div.head: Temporal discounting
div.p: Temporal discounting, also known as delay discounting, describes the phenomenon that a reward is valued less when one has to wait for it, compared to receiving it immediately (Frederick et al., 2002). Temporal discounting has significant implications for economic and financial decisions, influencing choices like opening a savings account or enrolling in a pension scheme (Angeletos et al., 2001). Temporal discounting preferences can be measured using inter-temporal choice tasks, where participants choose between two offers according to their own preferences: one is a smaller amount of reward delivered sooner (usually immediately), while the other is a larger amount of reward delivered after a longer delay ( Figure 1B). For example, people might need to choose between receiving £10 today or £30 next month. Typically, people favour smaller and sooner rewards over larger and delayed ones.

People's preferences for immediate rewards over delayed ones can be effectively captured through computational models of discounting, which quantify how delayed rewards devalue over time (Rachlin et al., 1991) Several studies have shown that preferences for temporal discounting are influenced by social contagion. For example, Garvert and colleagues (2015) used a delegated inter-temporal choice task to demonstrate that temporal discounting preferences were susceptible to social influence. Participants first completed a series of above-mentioned inter-temporal choices for themselves, and then learned and predicted the choices of another partner (who was either more impulsive or more patient). Finally, in the last phase, they alternated between making inter-temporal choices for themselves and on behalf of others. They found that participants were able to quickly and accurately learn their partner's preferences. Moreover, even though these choices had no direct consequences for the participants, their temporal discounting preferences shifted in the direction of their partner's. Another study using the same experimental design with a much larger sample size replicated this result and further found that people were generally more susceptible to patient social influence compared to impulsive social influence (Moutoussis et al., 2016). In another study, with a modification where participants made inter-temporal choices only for themselves after observation, they also found that participants aligned their temporal discounting preferences with those of others, and the degree of these changes was associated with the estimated differences between participants' personal preferences and those of others (Devaine & Daunizeau, 2017). Another study on group-based social norms also found that participants' temporal preferences shifted significantly closer to the norm after learning about it (Apps & Ramnani, 2017). The social contagion of temporal discounting preferences is so robust that even people diagnosed with autistic spectrum conditions, characterised by social impairments, demonstrated shifts in their temporal discounting preferences after learning about others' preferences (Thomas et al., 2022).

div.head: Effort discounting
div.p: Effort discounting refers to the phenomenon that the same reward is valued less if you have to exert effort, either physical or cognitive, to obtain it (Contreras-Huerta et al., 2020;Hull, 1943;Kool & Botvinick, 2018;Westbrook & Braver, 2015). Effort discounting preferences can be measured using effort-based decision-making paradigms, where participants are asked to make a series of choices between two options according to their preferences: one option offers a high reward but requires more effort, while the other offers a low reward with low effort ( Figure 1C). All things being equal, people tend to prefer options that require less effort, as effort is generally aversive (Chong et al., 2017;Hartmann et al., 2013;Klein-Flügge et al., 2015, 2016Skvortsova et al., 2014;Westbrook & Braver, 2015).

Effort discounting preferences may also be transmitted through social influence. For example, in an attitude alignment study, researchers probed how observing others effort discounting preferences influenced one's own (Devaine & Daunizeau, 2017). Participants were asked to make a series of effort-based choices, then to learn and predict someone else's choices (who was either more motivated or more apathetic), and finally to repeat the choice task themselves.

They found that, based on both model-free and model-based analyses, participants adjusted their effort discounting preferences to align with others after learning about and predicting others' preferences. The extent of these changes was correlated with the estimated differences between participants' own preferences and those of others. In addition, a recent study on challenge-seeking behaviour, in which participants chose between solving more challenging or less challenging maths word problems requiring different levels of cognitive effort, found that participants became more inclined toward challenge-seeking after observing others' challenge-seeking decisions (Ogulmus et al., 2024). These studies suggest that effort discounting preferences, in both physical and cognitive domains, are influenced to some extent by the preferences of others.

div.head: Moral preference
div.p: People sometimes make decisions that affect others and thus carry moral responsibility, such as offering help, refraining from causing harm, or imposing punishment (Lockwood et al., 2024). Such social decisions play a crucial role in promoting social cohesion and strengthening communal bonds (Fehr & Camerer, 2007;Fehr & Fischbacher, 2003;Y. E. Wu & Hong, 2022). These decisions often entail a trade-off between costs and benefits for oneself and others. Consequently, moral preferences can be assessed using tasks that trade-off selfinterest and the welfare of others (Crockett et al., 2014;Lockwood et al., 2020). For example, people could be asked to choose between a harmful option (high reward for themselves and high cost for others) and a helpful option (low reward for self and low cost for others; Figure 1D). Their choices reveal whether their moral preferences lean towards being more prosocial or more antisocial.

Intriguingly, moral economic preferences can also be influenced by other people (Lockwood et al., 2024). Yu and colleagues (2021) asked participants to make a series of private decisions that involved sacrificing some of their own money to reduce the intensity of painful electric shocks delivered to an anonymous stranger, before and after observing such decisions made by others (who were either more prosocial or more antisocial). They found observation of others led participants to adjust their moral preferences to more closely align with those of others, with this influence being stronger among participants who felt a greater sense of similarity to those they observed. Similar results were replicated in a study using an economic game that involved only monetary rewards and costs without pain (Panizza et al., 2021).

Participants were asked to make decisions between a default offer and an alternative offer that provided a lower payoff to themselves but could either benefit or disadvantage a stranger compared to the default. The authors demonstrated that, after observing and predicting the choices of extremely prosocial or antisocial others, participants' moral preferences became polarised to align more closely with those of the observed others.

Together, all these studies suggest that people's economic preferences are not necessarily fixed. Instead, the preferences of others around us fundamentally shape our risk, time, effort and moral economic preferences. In all these instances, simply learning what others value can make us more risky or antisocial, with important implications for understanding decisionmaking in everyday life.

div.head: Lifespan similarities and differences in social influence
div.p: As is the case in many research studies, the majority, including those reviewed above, have focused on testing young adults around the ages of 18-40. However, it is not surprising that our susceptibility to social influence may change throughout our lifespan. Social influence requires self-other distinction, which likely emerges in infancy (Lockwood et al., 2024). The age at which economic preferences occur is challenging to specify yet there is evidence that 5-6-year-olds can understand cost-benefit weightings of others' preferences (Jara-Ettinger et al. 2016). This is around the same age as the children who took part in the classical Bobo doll experiments by Albert Bandura, where observing an experimenter behaving aggressively towards a doll influenced similar aggressive behaviour in children who subsequently interacted with the same doll. These studies suggest that the propensity to confirm with others emerges early in our lives.

As we reach adolescence, several studies have documented how adolescents are more likely to engage in risk-seeking behaviour when in the presence of their peers. For example, epidemiological studies suggest adolescents are more likely to engage in illicit drug use or fast driving with peers present (Chein et al., 2011;Gardner & Steinberg, 2005;Pfeifer et al., 2011;Smith et al., 2014). However, this potential for peer influence can also result in positive outcomes, such as when others behave prosocially, i.e. helping or benefitting others (Armstrong-Carter et al., 2023;Do et al., 2019). There is some evidence that adolescents are particularly influenced by prosocial others compared to adults in their self report (Ahmed et al., 2020;Foulkes et al., 2018). Studies of economic choice behaviour, particularly risk-seeking, have been a focus of adolescent research given the possible real-world implications. These studies have integrated decision-making with computational modelling and shown stronger risk and temporal contagion in adolescents compared to adulthood (Reiter et al., 2019(Reiter et al., , 2021.

Importantly, in these incentivised tasks, picking the risky or temporally impulsive option negatively impacts the bonus payment of the participant, making the decision an irrational economic choice. Together, this body of work suggests that risk and temporal preferences may be subject to particularly high levels of contagion in adolescents compared to adults.

In older adults, fewer studies have been conducted, yet initial evidence suggests that heightened susceptibility to types of economic social influence may re-emerge. A recent study tested a relatively large group of young (N=76, aged 18-36) and older (N=78, aged 60-80) adults . They completed a social influence-based temporal discounting paradigm where they learnt the preferences of two other people (one more impulsive and one more patient) before making their choices again in different blocks.

They found that despite similar accuracy in learning others' preferences, older adults were relatively more susceptible to learning from an impulsive other person. Another study using a collaborative delay discounting task found no age differences (Bixter & Rogers, 2019).

However, participants' choices were not incentivised, as young adults received course credit and older adults received $30 regardless of their decisions. Consequently, their choices may not have reflected true preferences. Finally, a recent study using experience sampling showed that compared to young adults (aged 18-30 years), middle-aged (aged 31-59 years) and older adults (aged 60-80 years) were more likely to practise self-control when others were present enacting the desire, suggesting older people were less susceptible to social influence than young adults (Castrellon et al., 2024). The different patterns across these three studies highlight the importance of considering the domain of social influence studied and the age groups and incentives included. Longitudinal and mid-life samples with precise tasks and detailed computational models are needed to fully understand lifespan differences in social influence.

div.head: Neural mechanisms
div.p: Previous studies have identified several brain regions implicated in social influence within group settings. A coordinate-based meta-analysis of functional neuroimaging studies suggested that the activation of ventral striatum (VS), posterior medial frontal cortex (pMFC)/dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) as well as anterior insula (aIC) is associated with people's deviation from group opinions, and furthermore the deviation-related activation in the dmPFC predicts people's subsequent conformity to the group's majority opinion (H. Wu, 2016). To date, however, only a limited number of studies have investigated the neural mechanisms underlying social influence and contagion of economic preferences (Figure 3).

div.head: Functional and structural neuroimaging
div.p: Initial evidence from functional neuroimaging studies indicates that the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), a pivotal region involved in both economic and social decision-making, might play a crucial role in social influence and contagion of economic preferences. In the abovereviewed study by Garvert and colleagues (2015), they combined the delegated inter-temporal choice task with a repetition suppression procedure to reveal a region in the mPFC where activity predicted subsequent susceptibility to social influence. The authors attributed the alignment of one's own temporal preferences with those of others to the adaptive learning plasticity of value representations within the dmPFC. Another neuroimaging study of social influence of temporal discounting preferences found that dmPFC activation was associated with adherence to social norms, while ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) activation was linked to both social conformity and economic decision-making (Apps & Ramnani, 2017).

Similarly, in the context of risk-taking preferences, Suzuki and colleagues (2016) found that the dmPFC, along with the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC) and inferior parietal lobule (IPL), was associated with preference updating when participants learnt about others' risktaking preferences. In another study conducted in a group setting, the vmPFC was identified to encode the enhanced utility of options chosen by others, with its activation predicting subsequent conformity (Chung et al., 2015). The authors also found that participants showed increased response in the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) and aIC when faced with incongruent choices made by others, but only when they subsequently chose to conform.

Additionally, a study investigating the neurocomputational mechanisms of social influence on reinforcement learning found that there was increased functional coupling between the right temporoparietal junction (rTPJ) and the left putamen that predicted greater susceptibility to following the group consensus (Zhang & Gläscher, 2020).

Structural neuroimaging studies also support the central role of mPFC in social influence and contagion of economic preferences. A large longitudinal study integrating the delegated intertemporal choice task, computational modelling, and structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) techniques revealed that myelination within the mPFC could predict a reduction in participants' preference uncertainty (Reiter et al., 2021). This reduction, observed over a 1.5year period in people aged 14-24, was associated with their decreased level of susceptibility to social influence.

div.head: Causal neural manipulation
div.p: Studies using functional and structural neuroimaging offer valuable insights into the potential neural mechanisms underlying social influence and contagion of economic preferences. However, their correlational nature prevents definitive conclusions about whether these brain regions are causally involved.

Experimental methods for inducing changes in neural processes, such as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), have emerged as powerful tools for uncovering causal mechanisms in neuroscience research (Polanía et al., 2018). There is limited research on social influence and contagion of economic preferences using non-invasive brain stimulation. However, we can draw insights from studies examining social influence and contagion in other domains. For example, Klucharev and colleagues (2011) provided causal evidence for the role of the pMFC/dmPFC in social conformity within a group setting using TMS. In this study, participants evaluated the attractiveness of female faces both with and without receiving feedback from group opinions. By inhibiting the pMFC/dmPFC during the presentation of group opinions, participants were less likely to adjust their judgments to align with mismatching group opinions compared to when they received control or sham stimulation. Complementing this, Li and colleagues (2020) demonstrated that inhibiting the vmPFC increased social conformity during an ambiguous perceptual decisionmaking task. These results resonate with findings from functional and structural neuroimaging studies, highlighting the crucial role of prefrontal regions in social conformity.

Another important line of research into causal neural mechanisms involves studying patients with specific brain lesions (Vaidya et al., 2019). A recent study using a relatively large sample (N = 33) of rare participants with focal damage to the mPFC further highlights the central role of prefrontal regions in social influence and contagion of economic preferences . This study, which integrated a delegated intertemporal choice task, Bayesian computational modelling, and lesion-symptom mapping, revealed that the dmPFC plays a causal role in susceptibility to social influence, particularly when others were more impulsive in terms of temporal discounting preferences.

div.head: Future directions
div.p: Other people fundamentally shape our preferences and decisions in everyday life. Studies of social influence have incorporated economic paradigms of learning and deciding and shown that many preferences can be shifted to be more aligned with others. Future research is needed to thoroughly examine just how long these shifts in preference last as many studies have shown effects within the time frame of a task, yet it is uncertain whether people revert to their initial preferences in everyday life. Research has begun to document important differences across the lifespan in susceptibility to social influence, which are crucial to understand to prevent the negative consequences of maladaptive social influence. At the same time, we may be able to leverage people's susceptibility to social influence in positive ways, guiding them to make better financial decisions and decisions regarding health and wellbeing. New advances in neuroscience techniques like transcranial focussed ultrasound may help reveal the precise causal mechanisms underlying social influence and how it can be changed. Finally, many of the above studies have focussed on how we are influenced by individual other people with preferences quite different to ourselves, but the initial work on social influence highlighted just how powerful groups of people can be when they form a majority. Understanding how groups influence individuals or other groups is essential as we make decisions in a highly interconnected world.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Experimental tasks to measure different types of economic preferences. (A)

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Illustration of a shift in one's own economic preferences (Self) following social influence (Others). The participant's economic preferences are represented as normal probability distributions. After learning about the preference of Others by observation, the participant's own preference shifts towards that of Others, indicating an alignment of preferences driven by social influence.
. The cognitive and computational aspects of temporal discounting are discussed in more detail in other chapters of this volume (see Wagner, Knauth, & Peters, 2025; Hare et al., 2025; Lempert, 2025).

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Locations of neural responses during social influence and contagion of economic preferences from functional and structural neuroimaging studies. The marked locations correspond to the peak BOLD responses identified in MNI coordinates, displayed on MRI scans of the (A) medial plane, (B) lateral surface, and (C) coronal plane. Abbreviations: aIC, anterior insular cortex; BOLD, blood-oxygen-level-dependent; dACC, dorsal anterior cingulate cortex; dlPFC, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex; dmPFC, dorsomedial prefrontal cortex; IPL, inferior parietal lobule; MNI, Montreal Neurological Institute; mPFC, medial prefrontal cortex; TPJ, temporoparietal junction; vmPFC, ventromedial prefrontal cortex; VS, ventral striatum.
